title: splinemixmeta
text: Package splinemixmeta provides basic capabilities non-parametric meta-regression. one responses y, standard error, previous analyses, wants regress study-level explanatory variables x without assuming linearity, splinemixmeta allows arbitrary smooth relationship estimated smoothing spline. also possible include explanatory variables (assumed linear relationship y) random effects groupings. approach may referred “non-parametric meta-analysis”, “spline meta-regression”, “meta-splines”, similar terminology mash-ups. splinemixmeta works bringing together features mgcv building spline components mixmeta estimating general mixed-effects meta-analysis models. Specifically, splines mgcv can used random effects components, penalty matrix providing correlation structure spline coefficients, unknown smoothness parameter replaced unknown variance parameter, unpenalized directions spline parameter space (e.g. spline parameters representing linear relationship) moved fixed effects. resulting pieces set needed call mixmeta::mixmeta estimating model. Variance parameters always estimated REML (restricted maximum likelihood). important limits work. moment, spline choices covariance matrices can diagonalized supported. One can multiple components. practice, bivariate spline (.e. simply addition two univariate splines) potentially work bs = 'tp', although currently issue translating pieces mgcv splinemixmeta case. possible bs = 'mrf' also works, tested. See help(splinemixmeta) supported. estimation machinery particularly efficient may notably slow large models.

title: splinemixmeta
text: data simulation following pieces: 10 groups 5 data points . Since x values drawn independently, groups randomly associated x values. x uniformly distributed 0 20. Fixed effects y include intercept linear term. Random effects y include group effects. sinusoidal term y estimated spline, treated random effect. Residuals normally distributed sd = 1. Measurement errors (.e. estimation error previous studies y obtained) normally distributed standard deviations standard errors (se) previous studies. simulated uniformly distributed 0.1 0.3 show heterogeneity precision previous studies, due example different sample sizes.
code: set.seed(1) n <- 50 num_groups <- 10 group <- rep(1:num_groups, each = 5) |> factor() group_effects <- rnorm(length(group), 0, 0.3) x <- runif(n, 0, 20) coef_x <- 0.6 se <- runif(n, 0.1, 0.3) fx <- 1.5 * sin(2 * pi * x / 12) y <- 10 + coef_x * x + fx +    group_effects[group] +   fx + rnorm(n, 0, 1) + rnorm(n, 0, se) data <- data.frame(y, x, se, group) plot(y ~ x, data = data, col = group, pch = 19, main = "Simulated data (color = group)")
